prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Confidential Business Information and the Employment Relationship

para.paratext: An employer is entitled to protect almost any information of a business nature while the fiduciary employee remains in the employment relationship. For the most part, the courts, when determining whether a fiduciary employee should be prevented from using specific information following his or her departure, have focused on whether the information is unique to and provides a competitive edge or economic advantage to the employer. In this regard, the courts place an emphasis on the employee's relationship to customers and other employees and on the knowledge obtained by the employee during the employment, all of which evidence the degree of the fiduciary's ability to control the enterprise. Whether control was manifested through customers, other employees or actual knowledge is unimportant. The question of duty turns on the power that the employee had in determining the direction of the employer's interests, and in our context, is one of relative power in relation to the use of business information, opportunities and customers. The most sensitive confidential information will be that which relates to the customers of a business, including information relating to customer needs, purchasing history and contact persons.
Normally, there will be no misuse of confidential information, even by a fiduciary employee, where the information:
falls within the general knowledge available in the industry;
is easily ascertainable on inquiry; or
is available but for simple modifications.
